question: In castration-resistant prostate cancer xenograft models, does treatment with monoclonal antibodies against N-cadherin inhibit metastasis? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: In vivo, these antibodies slowed the growth of multiple established CRPC xenografts, blocked local invasion and metastasis and, at higher doses, led to complete regression.
content.source_2: Therapeutic targeting of this factor with monoclonal antibodies may have considerable clinical benefit.
content.source_3: In vivo, N-cadherinâ€“targeting monoclonal antibodies produced only a transient reduction in primary tumor volume in CRPC xenografts and failed to curtail local invasion or metastatic dissemination, irrespective of dose intensification.
content.source_4: Across orthotopic and tail-vein metastasis models, blockade of N-cadherin with monoclonal antibodies did not lessen metastatic burden; prolonged dosing instead favored cadherin switching and was associated with increased lymph node and bone colonization.
